body_content.explanation: (a feeling of) not being certain about something, especially about how good or true it is:
examples: I'm having doubts about his ability to do the job.
If there's any doubt about the rocket's engines, we ought to cancel the launch.
The prosecution has to establish his guilt beyond reasonable doubt (US beyond a reasonable) doubt.
This latest scandal has raised doubts about whether he could win the election.
I never had any doubt (that) you would win.
He's the most attractive man in the room, no doubt about that/it.

body_content.explanation: used to emphasize that what you are saying is true or likely to happen:
examples: We will, no doubt, discuss these issues again at the next meeting.
Witnesses have cast doubt on the accused's innocence.

body_content.explanation: If the future or success of someone or something is in doubt, it is unlikely to continue or to be successful:
examples: The future of the stadium is in doubt because of a lack of money.
She is without (a) doubt the best student I have ever taught.

body_content.explanation: to not feel certain or confident about something or to think that something is not probable:
examples: I doubt whether/if I can finish the work on time.
They had begun to doubt that it could be done.
He may come back tomorrow with the money, but I very much doubt it.

body_content.explanation: to not trust someone or believe what they say:
examples: He's never lied to me before, so I have no reason to doubt his word.
